quote: Despite the advancements brought by neural network-based methods like SuperPoint and ALIKED, these modern approaches lag behind classical ones such as SIFT in keypoint localization accuracy due to their lack of sub-pixel precision.

We propose a novel network that enhances any detector with sub-pixel precision by learning an offset vector for detected features, thereby eliminating the need for designing specialized sub-pixel accurate detectors.
Our proposed Keypoint Refinement module is directly trained with a geometric objective.
The proposed method consistently improves both detectors in almost all metrics.
We evaluate the proposed sub-pixel refinement method in conjunction with the gold standard SuperPoint [20] and the recent ALIKED [78] detectors.

This observation underscores the nuanced effectiveness of sub-pixel refinement in enhancing feature-based estimations of fundamental matrices, highlighting the proposed method’s broad applicability and potential for improving feature detection and matching processes.
The integration of the sub-pixel refinement mechanism with vanilla SuperPoint consistently improves performance across all evaluated accuracy metrics.
Our method improved the combination of SuperPoint and mutual nearest neighbor matching (SP+MNN) from 27% to 33% Mean Matching Accuracy (MMA) at 1px.
This work introduces a novel post-processing procedure designed to endow any learned feature detection model with sub-pixel accuracy, addressing a critical limitation of recent detectors.
The culmination of these improvements is most notable when all modules are applied in tandem, resulting in the optimal enhancement of feature detection capabilities.
Recently, transformers have become the most popular neural network design.
Compared to LoFTR’s fine module, our method performs significantly efficiently in both model size and inference time while only marginally worse for relative pose estimation.
ASLFeat: Learning local features of accurate shape and localization.
Lightglue: Local feature matching at light speed.
Note that our method consistently increases the number of inliers, but it does not always lead to more accurate relative poses.
